Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2012 08:54AM rakulynda wrote: I've been on Navelbine for 6 months and have not lost any hair. Since the side effects are cumulative over time, the fatigue is the worst of it. I can pretty much count on laying around for 2 days, 2 days after infusion and then rebound. Does that make sense? I also have a bit of neuropathy on the bottom of one foot but l-glutamine helps alot (over the counter). No nauseau either and I have mets to the stomach. And peritoneum and bones. Navelbine for me is WAY easier than Taxol but harder than Xeloda. Best of luck with your decision and hoping whatever you decide on is easy on you.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 07:35AM rakulynda wrote: Mary, you have received some wonderful advice here and I really can't offer much more except perhaps one thing.  During an especially scary time with a recent progression I started to feel death was at my door and HOW DO I DEAL????  I came upon a book, "Life After Death" by Kubler-Ross and it helped so so much with those "death" fears.  It's an easy read and may not help everyone but it sure got me over a hump.  Hugs to you.   Lynda

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2011 06:00PM rakulynda wrote: I was on Taxol/Avastin when first dx with metastisis to liver, bones ovary and omentum.  Unfortunately had liver progression and am now on Xeloda/Zometa which has been successful for meeting the stable boy.  I had enormous fatique and total hair loss on taxol and nose bleeds from the Avastin.  Just goes to show you how different people with the same dx have different outcomes.  Hoping this combo kicks cancer butt for you.  Lynda

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 11:00AM rakulynda wrote: So glad to hear all went well for you. I had TRAM reconstruction 9 years ago (immediately following mastectomy) and even though the first 2 weeks of recovery were tough, I absolutely love my new breast and had no post-surgery issues. Having a tummy tuck was an added bonus and the fact that the new breast gains and loses weight with the rest of you never gives you a lop-sided look. Although the breast remains numb, my "tunnel" area along the abdomen did regain feeling after a couple of years. Happy you are over the worst of it - congratulations!

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: rakulynda wrote: Is there anybody out there with a similar dx or knows of anyone with something similar?  I'm so frustrated, I could scream and can't seem to connect with anyone who is or knows someone with this type of metastisis.  My lobular returned last year after 8 years to bones and abdominal area.  PET/CT scans couldn't pinpoint where - maybe the ovary, colon, omentum, liver, peritoneum.  I've lost 60 pounds in 8 months.  Well, it seems MRI is the best imagaing for me and yesterday's results say..."Diffusion weighted images of the upper abdomen demonstrate abnormal restricted diffusion along the peritoneum of the anterior surface of the diaphragm bilaterally, of concern for peritonteal tumor implants.  This appearance is new from the 11/9/11 exam."  Also, "Abnormal restricted diffusion involving the mucosa and submucosal tissues of the body and fundus of the stomach ...of concern for gastric metastatic disease.  Well, lucky me, "Widespread osseous metastases, not significantly changed".. Bone mets are so widespread, they don't even talk specifically about where they are.  My onc has thrown a bunch of chemos at it : Taxol/Avastin :progression, Xeloda: progression and now Navelbine which doesn't seem to be doing much so now she's thrown Aromosin in the mix.  I've read that only .03 % of lobular ca goes to this area.  Just feeling like I'm on a slowly sinking ship and nothing is working.  I'm so so so fortunate that I have no pain, minimal SE's and am still fully functional besides the weight loss.  It's terrifying to lose just 1 pound.   Just ranting and hoping to find someone to connect with. Dx 9/2002, ILC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Almost a month here... lisalock lisalock

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 09:27AM rakulynda wrote: I've been waiting for a post like this!  I thought I was the only one out there wondering about this topic.  I have mets to the ovary and omentum which has caused constant nausea and big weight loss (35 lbs without trying).  I have a friend who grows weed in her garden and the relief I get from smoking two or three puffs at dinner time is wonderful!  It seems to quell the nausea and gives me a bit of an appetite where compazine has had no effect whatsoever.  I would smoke it throughout the day but don't want that "high" feeling and accompanying sleepiness during the day.  I'll be most happy when AZ dispensaries are open so I can choose a variety that targets just nausea and appetite.
Posts.Title: Pot ~ weed ~ and other cures. :) lisa34lisa radiant

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 04:44AM rakulynda wrote: Nanka - my weight loss was incredibly fast, 60 lbs. in 5 months. It started with early satiety (feeling full very quickly when eating) and w/ this concern, saw my PCP who ordered a CT. Sure enough, mets were found in bones and stomach. I've yet to hear of anyone else with mets to the stomach but then, ILC goes to weird places but it seems incredibly rare. These symptoms, I've heard, are similar to ovarian mets. If your weight loss continues at a fast rate, get it checked out. I never suspected that rapid weight loss was a symptom of mets. I'm 2 years out now from the mets dx and doing very well and maintaining my weight at a sveldt but skinny 120 lbs. Lynda

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 10:19AM rakulynda wrote: Hope it's ok to butt in here.  Fortunately I have no pain to deal with, just tremendous weight loss (60 lbs in 8 months) thanks to the mets in and around my stomach from crappy, sneaky lobular.  My onc. and nurses suggested medical marijuana for appetite loss.  AZ just passed the medical mj law but is still wrangling over the dispensary thing.  Dumb.
Posts.Title: Pot ~ weed ~ and other cures. :) lisa34lisa radiant

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 08:49AM rakulynda wrote: I've been on Navelbine for 4 rounds now, 3 weeks on, one week off. Luckily wbc have never dropped but the fatique is bad and I think cumulative. Sometimes get horrible leg cramps which usually pass quickly. The worst part is the constipation so be sure to take Ducolax day before, day of and day after treatment. Onc. just threw Aromosin in the mix and I'm drowning in night sweats. Scans in a month or so - have never been able to get my tumor markers to budge out of the 250 range. For me, Navelbine has been a cake walk compared to Taxol. Good luck to you all!
Posts.Title: Need Info on Navelbine LuAnnH jcb51

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 02:07AM rakulynda wrote: I've been on navelbine for about 20 rounds now along with Zometa and Aromisin. Sorry I don't know what the doseage is but I get it 3 weeks on, one week off. I have neuropathy in my right toes but if I take the l-glutamine daily, I get tremendous relief - just get lazy about taking it regularly. No problems with blood counts but have found the fatigue is definitely cumulative. . 2 days after infusion I know I'll be on the sofa for 2 days so I just plan around it by preparing soups and easy to heat up foods in advance, get out my favorite pillow and blankie, set up Netflix and let myself succomb. The fatigue used to make me so angry and depressed but now just try to go with it. MRI scan May 1 to see if anything is working - CT/PET scans don't show much with my lobular, if not, it's on to Abraxane. Nono no no, I wanna keep my hair! It amazes me how we all react so differently to the same tx. Lynda
Posts.Title: For those on navelbine LuAnnH onedayatatime

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 09:48AM rakulynda wrote: Just finished my 7th infusion of Navelbine and it's been very tolerable for me as opposed to the worst ever: Taxol.  No hair loss but some nausea and a steroid along with Aloxi has taken care of that.  Do all my housecleaning the day after chemo thanks to that steroid!  WBC and RBC remain normal, very little constipation but am just starting to sense a little nueropathy in my right little toe.  Tumor markers have dropped for the first time in a year and next weeks abdominal MRI will hopefully show regression of all the lobular cancer in and around my stomach.
Posts.Title: Need Info on Navelbine LuAnnH jcb51

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2012 10:13AM rakulynda wrote: I had a similar experience.  Results of my first bone scan showed a fractured 7th rib.  Never had any pain or had any idea this had happened!?!!??  No treatment for the rib.
Posts.Title: Anyone had this?!? raro rakulynda

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 09:52PM rakulynda wrote: Hi Lulu I was originally dx with ILC in 2002 and after tx was told I was " cured". Funny as I'd never heard there was a cure for ca. Fast forward 9 years later with mets to bones, peritoneum and stomach. You know how ILC goes to strange places, right? I've yet to find anyone out there with mets to the stomach. Been living w/mets for 2 years now and have been thru 3 chemos in attempts at regression but luckily have remained stable all this time with TM always staying in the 200-250 range. Luckily, it seems ILC is slower growing and once you're on a tx plan that works for you, you will be here for many years to come. I don't follow any "special" diet and try to get as many calories as possible after losing 60 lbs in 6 months. Some days are good, some are not but isn't that true for everyone?

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 12:45PM rakulynda wrote: Thanks so much all of you for responding! It's strange how we gain comfort from others in the same predicament. Lynn-swims, your dx sounds so similar to mine. I'm finding more and more that my stomach is so uncomfortable so often that I sit curled up in a ball. Hoping this Aromasin helps me to gain a little weight! I discovered my mets when I started having trouble eating a full meal and after a few months, had it checked out. Stupid ca in and around my stomach and the stomach cannot expand to accept food. Never never suspected the inability to eat much would be a symptom of mets. I'm starting now to realize that I'm losing strength and stamina and it saddens me to experience this gradual decline. :(

Posts.Content: rakulynda wrote: Saw my oncologist yesterday and tumour markers are creeping down with Navelbine!  Yipee!.  Problem is trying to maintain my weight at 120 (I'm 5'7").  Lost a couple more pounds.  When I went into the treatment room that was stuffed with all breast cancer ladies, had a major meltdown for all to see.  I really needed some privacy at that moment and the nurses were sweeter than sweet, looking into my eyes and giving me hugs, which only made me cry more.  Next treatment, I'll be looking for that chair off in the corner but yesterday there was only one chair open right in the middle of the room.  Stupid ILC in and around my stomach but liver is clear!  That meltdown really caught me off guard and all I wanted to do was run screaming around that treatment room punching stuff.  AAAARRRGGGGHH!!! Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2012 09:30AM rakulynda wrote: No experience (yet) with Abraxane but I found Xeloda very easy.  Had no issues with the hand/foot thing, no fatigue and it sure was nice to keep my hair.  No infusions was another plus.  Unfortunately it didn't do the job for me so now on to Navelbine.
Posts.Title: Xeloda vs Abraxane? What would your choice be? lovinmomma WifeandMom

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 10:10AM rakulynda wrote: Maddy - here's prayers that your treatments will provide relief!!  I hate this stupid disease.  I have mets to bones and stomach (thanks lobular).  Although my onc. is now concentrating on the cancer in my stomach (on Navelbine and Zometa), my original bone scan didn't show anything but a later CT scan showed "mottling" in spine, sternum, ribs, hips.  Anyone ever heard of "mottling"?  Bone scan did show a fracture of the 7th rib but fortunately, have had no pain from any of the bone involvement and never knew the rib was fractured.  So strange.  Love to all my boney sisters. Lynda
Posts.Title: Bone Mets- "hundreds" of lesions? MaddyMason chrissyb

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 09:16AM rakulynda wrote: I think "the perfect storm" is the perfect answer. Thinking back on all the "bad" stuff I ate or was exposed to living in a western country - all were contributing factors to my bc. I wonder about swimming as a kid in the Fox river in WI where there were paper mills spewing junk upriver. I wonder about having to paint the interiors of my family's rental units. I wonder about the toxins I was exposed to while working in my ceramics studio. etc, etc, etc. Our family ate all the typical western food - steak, cereal with milk, meatloaf with gravy not to mention my parents both smoking in the car with the windows rolled up. I'm sure I did and ate everything "wrong" but at the time, no one knew. My point is that we got it (bc), and we deal with it the best way we know how and move forward trying to live a full and meaningful life. I pray for my daughter. . . .
